name: Causal Inference & Root Cause Analysis Quality Rubric

criteria.name: Effect Definition Clarity
criteria.description: Effect/outcome is clearly defined, quantified, and temporally bounded

scoring.1: Effect vaguely described (e.g., 'things are slow'), no quantification or timeline
scoring.2: Effect described but lacks quantification or timeline details
scoring.3: Effect clearly described with either quantification or timeline
scoring.4: Effect clearly described with quantification and timeline, baseline comparison present
scoring.5: Effect precisely quantified with magnitude, timeline, baseline, and impact assessment

criteria.name: Hypothesis Generation
criteria.description: Multiple competing hypotheses generated systematically (not just confirming first theory)

scoring.2: 2 hypotheses mentioned, one clearly favored without testing
scoring.3: 3+ hypotheses listed, some testing of alternatives
scoring.4: Multiple hypotheses systematically generated using techniques (5 Whys, Fishbone, etc.)
scoring.5: Comprehensive hypothesis generation with proximate/root causes distinguished and confounders identified

criteria.name: Root Cause Identification
criteria.description: Distinguishes root cause from proximate causes and symptoms

scoring.1: Confuses symptom with cause (e.g., 'app crashed because server returned error')
scoring.2: Identifies proximate cause but claims it as root without deeper investigation
scoring.3: Distinguishes proximate from root cause, but mechanism unclear
scoring.4: Clear root cause identified with explanation of why it's root (not symptom)
scoring.5: Root cause clearly identified with full causal chain from root → proximate → effect

criteria.name: Causal Model Quality
criteria.description: Causal relationships mapped with mechanisms, confounders noted

scoring.1: No causal model, just list of correlations
scoring.2: Basic cause → effect stated without mechanisms or confounders
scoring.3: Causal chain sketched, mechanism mentioned but not detailed
scoring.4: Clear causal chain with mechanisms explained and confounders identified
scoring.5: Comprehensive causal model with chains, mechanisms, confounders, mediators/moderators mapped

criteria.name: Temporal Sequence Verification
criteria.description: Verified that cause precedes effect (necessary for causation)

scoring.2: Timeline mentioned but not used to test causation
scoring.3: Temporal sequence checked for main hypothesis
scoring.4: Temporal sequence verified for all hypotheses, rules out reverse causation
scoring.5: Detailed timeline analysis shows cause clearly precedes effect with lag explained

criteria.name: Counterfactual Testing
criteria.description: Tests 'what if cause absent?' using control groups, rollbacks, or baseline comparisons

scoring.4: Strong counterfactual test (e.g., control group, rollback experiment, A/B test)
scoring.5: Multiple counterfactual tests with consistent results strengthening causal claim

criteria.name: Mechanism Explanation
criteria.description: Explains HOW cause produces effect (not just THAT they correlate)

scoring.3: Basic mechanism explained ('X causes Y because...')
scoring.4: Clear mechanism with pathway and intermediate steps
scoring.5: Detailed mechanism with supporting evidence (logs, metrics, theory) and plausibility assessment

criteria.name: Confounding Control
criteria.description: Identifies and controls for confounding variables (third factors causing both X and Y)

scoring.1: No mention of confounding, assumes correlation = causation
scoring.2: Aware of confounding but doesn't identify specific confounders
scoring.3: Identifies 1-2 potential confounders but doesn't control for them
scoring.4: Identifies confounders and attempts to control (stratification, regression, matching)
scoring.5: Comprehensive confounder identification with rigorous control methods and sensitivity analysis

criteria.name: Evidence Quality & Strength
criteria.description: Uses high-quality evidence (experiments > observational > anecdotes) and assesses strength systematically

scoring.1: Relies solely on anecdotes or single observations
scoring.2: Uses weak evidence (cross-sectional correlation) without acknowledging limits
scoring.3: Uses moderate evidence (longitudinal data, multiple observations)
scoring.4: Uses strong evidence (quasi-experiments, well-controlled studies) with strength assessed
scoring.5: Uses highest-quality evidence (RCTs, multiple converging lines of evidence) with Bradford Hill criteria or similar framework

criteria.name: Confidence & Limitations
criteria.description: States confidence level with justification, acknowledges alternative explanations and uncertainties

scoring.1: Overconfident claims without justification, no alternatives considered
scoring.2: States conclusion without confidence level or uncertainty
scoring.4: States justified confidence level, acknowledges alternatives and key limitations
scoring.5: Explicit confidence assessment with justification, comprehensive limitations, alternative explanations evaluated, unresolved uncertainties noted

thresholds.very_good: Average score ≥ 4.0 (high-stakes decisions - major product/engineering changes)
thresholds.good: Average score ≥ 3.5 (medium-stakes decisions - feature launches, incident postmortems)
thresholds.acceptable: Average score ≥ 3.0 (low-stakes decisions - exploratory analysis, hypothesis generation)
thresholds.needs_rework: Average score < 3.0 (insufficient for decision-making, redo analysis)

stakes_guidance.low_stakes: Exploratory root cause analysis, hypothesis generation: aim for ≥ 3.0
stakes_guidance.medium_stakes: Incident postmortems, feature failure analysis, process improvements: aim for ≥ 3.5
stakes_guidance.high_stakes: Major architectural decisions, safety-critical systems, policy evaluation: aim for ≥ 4.0

common_failure_modes: Correlation-causation fallacy: Assuming X causes Y just because they correlate
Post hoc ergo propter hoc: 'After this, therefore because of this' - temporal sequence ≠ causation
Stopping at proximate cause: Identifying immediate trigger without tracing to root
Cherry-picking evidence: Only considering evidence that confirms initial hypothesis
Ignoring confounders: Not considering third variables that cause both X and Y
No mechanism: Claiming causation without explaining how X produces Y
Reverse causation: Assuming X causes Y when actually Y causes X
Single-case fallacy: Generalizing from one observation without testing consistency
usage_instructions: Rate each criterion on 1-5 scale. Calculate average. For important decisions (postmortems, product changes), minimum score is 3.5. For high-stakes decisions (infrastructure, safety, policy), aim for ≥4.0. Red flags: score <3 on Temporal Sequence, Counterfactual Testing, or Mechanism Explanation means causal claim is weak. Red flag on Confounding Control means correlation may be spurious.
